s.text: An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
An ordinary prosecutor may decide to forgo charges so that he can devote his energies to a case that is more important and easier to win.
In his litigious thickets, Walsh loses sight of the question of why anyone should still care.
Reagan points at sights outside the window and tries to remember irrelevant anecdotes about Mikhail Gorbachev and Margaret Thatcher.

Though he was still thinking about indicting Reagan in late 1992, Walsh never found effective proof that Reagan was lying when he testified that he hadn't known about the diversion of profits to the Contras.
The passing of a petty scandal, the resignation of a target, even a change in administrations is no obstacle, as we know from the many barnacle-encrusted investigators still hanging on.
The passing of a petty scandal, the resignation of a target, even a change in administrations is no obstacle, as we know from the many barnacle-encrusted investigators still hanging on.
Were he to announce that his scandal didn't justify criminal proceedings after all, he would be declaring himself a failure who had wasted the public's time and money.
Indicting him was an exercise in prosecutorial pique, doomed to fail.
Indicting him was an exercise in prosecutorial pique, doomed to fail.
Indicting him was an exercise in prosecutorial pique, doomed to fail.
Perhaps now that he's set his frustrations down in a book, Lawrence Walsh will be able to do the same.

Walsh quite rightly points out that his investigation was undermined at the outset by the congressional Iran-Contra committee's decision to grant immunity to Oliver North and White House National Security Adviser John Poindexter who, along with the conveniently deceased CIA Director William Casey, appear to have been the chief conspirators in the plot.
For an ambitious man who had been frustrated in his career, the appointment was a heaven-sent extra chance, and it appeared at first to be a bit of brilliant casting.
